title: Wearable tech might be good fit at Alphabet
text:
A deal with Fitbit could provide Google’s parent company with another platform for its ads business.

No need to strap a fitness tracker on Fitbit investors to see how their hearts race at the possibility of a buyer for the company. Reports of interest from Alphabet sent shares up more than 30 per cent on Monday.

A wearable tech company trying to ward off the existential threat of smartphones is not exactly a moonshot project for Alphabet, parent company of search engine Google.

It may be looking at consumer devices to be a new source of revenue growth, but an investment in Fitbit appears to clash with an existing interest in smartphones, shown by the recent release of a new Pixel device and a $US40 million ($58 million) investment in smartwatch technology from Fossil.

Fitbit makes most of its money selling devices but has had mixed success. Its shares trade far below the $US20 they listed at in 2015. If a deal does emerge, it may end up being more about data than devices. Fitbit devices track location and biometrics — both useful bits of information.

It has also been working on a services business, Fitbit Health Solutions, which includes functions such as coaching.

Third-quarter earnings released on Monday show that Alphabet’s advertising business sales grew 17 per cent on the previous year to almost $US34 billion. This is respectable but not enough to prevent a rise in costs from squeezing profit margins.
description: A deal with Fitbit could provide Google’s parent company another platform for its ads business.
